options: How many base pairs the human genome is made of?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The most common cause of peripheral neuropathy is diabetes mellitus.
The most common pattern of diabetic neuropathy is an ascending, distal symmetric, sensorimotor polyneuropathy (glove and stocking type).
The most common type of hereditary neuropathy is Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.

options: Which of the following describes the non-coding regulatory RNAs?
Transcribed from protein-coding regions of DNA and translated to regulatory protein
Transcribed from protein-coding regions of DNA but never translated
Transcribed from non-protein-coding regions of DNA and translated to regulatory protein
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease. It is most commonly associated with chromosome 17.
It is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. The most common variant of this condition is CMT1A. It is caused by a duplication of a region on chromosome 17 that includes the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene.
It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop with no numbness or tingling. There is reduced sensation to all modalities with reduced muscle stretch reflexes. Atrophy of the muscles below the knee leads to inverted champagne bottle legs.
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1129.jpeg]

options: What is the study of heritable changes in gene expression that are not caused by alterations in DNA sequence?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is most commonly associated with thymic hyperplasia (65% of cases).
Thymoma is seen in around 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis.
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of
the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction.
There is a characteristic pattern of muscle involvement. Lid and extraocular muscles (diplopia and ptosis) are involved early in the disease course. The facial muscles weakness can produce a snarling expression, weakness in chewing, and nasal timbre to the voice. Weakness increases with repeated use of the muscles and improves with rest. The reflexes are normal in this condition.

options: Micro-RNA are involved during which of the following stages?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive
stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength.
Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.
Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.

options: Which of the following statements is false about microRNAs?
They are involved in cell differentiation and carcinogenesi
Mature forms of microRNAs are single stranded
subject: Pathology
explanation: Dermatomyositis is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children. Two types of dermatomyositis are known—juvenile and adult.

options: What is the most common cause of cell injury?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The muscle biopsy shows myofiber atrophy accentuated at the edges of the fascicles (perifascicular atrophy). The biopsy along with the history is suggestive of dermatomyositis. It is associated
with perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates.
Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1130.jpeg]
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1131.jpeg]
Note: Viral myositis occurs 1-7 days after a viral infection (HIV-1, coxsackievirus). Muscle weakness and tenderness are seen. There are raised CK levels, muscle necrosis without inflammation, and positive urine myoglobin.

options: Which of the following statements is false?
Atrophy is a type of reversible cell injury
Plasma membrane blebbing occurs in reversible cell injury
On removal of stimulus, necrosis can be reversed
subject: Pathology
explanation:
This patient has developed paraneoplastic dermatomyositis. Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis and juvenile dermatomyositis.
It presents as gradual, symmetric muscle weakness and myalgias, typically affecting the proximal muscles first. Fine movements controlled by distal muscles are affected late in the disease.
Myopathic changes and elevation in serum creatine kinase levels suggest muscle damage.
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1132.jpeg]

options: Which among the following is not a feature of reversible cell injury?
Large amorphous densities in the mitochondria
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Antibodies to cN1A are seen in inclusion-body myositis.
It is the most common inflammatory myopathy in patients >65 years.
Patients present with slowly progressive muscle weakness that tends to be most severe in the quadriceps and the distal upper extremity muscles. Dysphagia from esophageal and pharyngeal muscle involvement can also occur.
Laboratory studies usually show modestly elevated creatine kinase levels. Most myositis-associated autoantibodies are absent but are positive for antibodies to cN1A.

options: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury?
Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition.
Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration.
Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern.
In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show reduced staining.

subject: Pathology
explanation:
NARP syndrome - Neuropathy Ataxia Retinitis Pigmentosa syndrome is described as a mitochondrial function disorder.
NARP syndrome is due to a point mutation of the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene. It has 2 phenotypes:
NARP
Maternally inherited Leigh syndrome (MILS)
It is characterized by moderate, diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia on MRI. The severity of the syndrome corresponds to the mutant mitochondrial DNA load in the tissues.

options: Which of the following statements about cellular adaptations is correct?
Hyperplasia involves synthesis of intracellular component
Atrophy is defined as decrease in cell size
Atrophy is the decrease in number and size of cell
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The following conditions are mitochondrial disorders:
Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers
Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
Kearns-Sayre syndrome
The proteins and tRNAs in the mitochondria may be encoded by 2 sets of genes:
Nuclear genome - Mendelian inheritance patterns
Mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) - maternally inherited, as the oocyte contributes all the mitochondria in the embry
Mitochondrial disorders are caused by mutations in the mitochondrial genome.
The most consistent pathologic change in skeletal muscle is abnormal aggregates of mitochondria.
These are seen preferentially in the subsarcolemmal area of affected myofibers, producing a ragged red fibers appearance, as shown below.
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1133.jpeg]

options: A patient with long-standing hypertension develops left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following transcription factors do not play a role in this?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is most commonly caused by the mutation of the genes encoding calcium channels (CALCL1A3).
It is an autosomal dominant ion channel myopathy with an onset in adolescence. Males are usually affected more than females. It presents as proximal muscle weakness. Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be involved.
The diagnosis is established by a low serum potassium level during an attack, after excluding secondary causes.
Ion channel myopathies include the following:

options: How does myosin change during muscle hypertrophy?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Mutations affecting the chloride channel CLC1 cause myotonia congenita. The resulting deficiency of CLC1 is responsible for the characteristic myotonia in myotonic dystrophy.
Ion channel myopathies:

options: Both physiological hyperplasia and hypertrophy are simultaneously seen in which of the following individuals?
A 24-year-old man vigorously training for an athletic race
A 35-year-old woman regularly taking combined oral contraceptive pill
A 50-year-old man with proliferation of liver cells following transplantation
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Glial hamartia are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2). These are microscopic nodular collections of glial cells at abnormal locations, often in the superficial and deep layers of the cerebral cortex.
NF2 is associated with the following:
Bilateral eighth-nerve schwannomas
Multiple meningiomas
Gliomas - typically ependymomas of the spinal cord
Nonneoplastic lesions - schwannosis, meningioangiomatosis, and glial hamartia
Option A: NF 1 is associated with neurofibromas of all types, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, gliomas of the optic nerve, other glial tumors, hamartomatous lesions, and pheochromocytomas.
Option C: Tuberous sclerosis is associated with hamartomas within the CNS in the form of cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. Other lesions include subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma, renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and cysts in the liver, kidneys, and pancreas.
Option D: Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with hemangioblastomas of the CNS and cysts involving the pancreas, liver, and kidneys, and have a propensity to develop renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.
NOTE: A hamartia is not considered to be a tumor and is distinct from a hamartoma. A hamartoma is a benign neoplasm characterized by tissue misarrangement similar to a hamartia.

options: Which among the following do not usually undergo hyperplasia?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Focal collections of pseudo-Meissner corpuscles or tactile-like bodies (cells mimicking the appearance of Meissner corpuscles) is a feature of diffuse neurofibroma.
Note: Meissner corpuscles consist of a cutaneous nerve ending responsible for transmitting the sensations of fine, discriminative touch and vibration.

options: Which of the following is an example of physiological atrophy?
Atrophy of the legs of a bedridden patient
Atrophy of the arm muscles following a nerve injury
Muscle wasting in a child suffering from marasmu
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP). The area affected in this condition is the myelin sheath (marked as 2 in the image).
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1134.jpeg]
Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disease that causes fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy. It is a T-cell mediated immune response.
GBS is usually associated with a history of upper respiratory infection (URI) or acute gastroenteritis (AGE) 1-3 weeks prior. The causative organisms may be Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
It presents with the following features:
Ascending motor paralysis (lower limbs > upper limbs)
Sensory deficits may or may not be seen
Deep tendon reflexes - absent
Transient bladder dysfunction - severe cases
Autonomic manifestations - loss of vasomotor control, postural hypotension, cardiac dysrhythmias
Histological examination shows inflammation of peripheral nerves, manifested as perivenular and endoneurial infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and a few plasma cells. On electron microscopy, an early effect on myelin sheaths is seen. There is segmental demyelination induced by the actions of activated macrophages.
There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome:
Demyelinating
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - most common
Axonal
Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)
Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)

options: The cross-section of the brain of an 84-year-old man with dyslipidemia is given below, in comparison with a normal brain. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Cerebellum is involved in tonsillar herniation.
Tonsillar herniation refers to the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This pattern of herniation is life-threatening because it causes brainstem compression and compromises vital respiratory and cardiac centers in the medulla.

options: Which of the following is the most common type of metaplasia?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Primary central nervous system lymphoma is the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed individuals, including those with AIDS and immunosuppression after transplantation.
The vast majority of primary central nervous system lymphomas are of B-cell origin. Overall, primary central nervous system lymphomas are aggressive and have worst outcome. The Epstein-Barr virus plays an important role in the pathogenesis of HIV-related primary central nervous system lymphoma.

options: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called:
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.
The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.
The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given below:
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_108.jpeg, Pathology_img_1125.jpeg]

options: Which of the following conditions is an example of connective tissue metaplasia?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Most of the meningiomas are benign tumors and very rarely metastasize to CSF.
The primary intracerebral malignancies that may cause metastases to the subarachnoid space are:
Glioblastoma (GBM)
Anaplastic astrocytoma
Medulloblastoma
Ependymoma
Pineoblastomas
Oligodendroglioma
Leptomeningeal metastases, also known as carcinomatous meningitis, refer to the spread of malignant cells through the CSF space. These cells can originate both in primary CNS tumors (e.g. drop-metastases), as well as from distant tumors that have metastasized (hematogenous spread).
The most common secondary tumors that spread to CSF are breast cancer > lung cancer >
melanoma > GI malignancies.
Contrast MRI is the investigation of choice and shows leptomeningeal enhancement and tumor scattered over the brain in a ‘sugar-coated’ manner.
Peripheral nerves & Neuromuscular pathology

options: Deficiency in which of the following vitamins can lead to metaplastic transformation in the lung?
subject: Pathology
explanation:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.
On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.
Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.

options: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other
subject: Pathology
explanation:
Max Joseph’s space is a histopathological feature of lichen planus. Histological features of lichen planus:
Orthokeratosis, parakeratosis, thickening of the stratum granulosum.
Acanthosis with the formation of colloid bodies (also known as Civatte bodies/Sabouraud bodies)
Liquefactive degeneration of the stratum basale, with separation from the underlying lamina propria, as a result of desmosome loss, creating small spaces (Max Joseph spaces)
Infiltration of T cells in a band-like pattern into the dermis “hugging” the basal layer (interface dermatitis)
 [Image Reference: Pathology_img_6.jpeg, Pathology_img_105.jpeg, Pathology_img_1099.png]
